revision.text:
[[File:Disney College Program logo.svg|right|250px|Disney Theme Parks & Resorts College Program Logo]] The '''Disney College Program''' is a [[United States|U.S.]] national [[internship]] program operated by [[The Walt Disney Company]], located at the [[Walt Disney World Resort]] and the [[Disneyland Resort]]. The Disney College Program recruits students (18 years and older) and all majors for a semester-long paid internship program working at the Walt Disney World Resort or Disneyland Resort.
==History== The first Disney College Program began in 1981. In the early days, the College Program consisted of just over 200 students from 20 schools working in only one theme park, the [[Magic Kingdom]].<ref name=dailynebraskan>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynebraskan.com/news/1.1017249-1.1017249|title=Opportunities await Disney College Program participants|first=Amy|last=Nichols|date=2001-10-30|publisher=dailynebraskan.com|accessdate=2009-03-06}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> At that time it was known as '''The Magic Kingdom College Program (MKCP)'''. In October 1982, program participants could work at Epcot as well as the Magic Kingdom and the program was known as '''The Walt Disney World College Program''',<ref name=cpbrochure>{{Cite book|title=Walt Disney World College Program|year=1983|format=brochure|publisher=Walt Disney Productions|accessdate=2009-03-05}}</ref> employing approximately 500 college students each spring, summer and fall session. From the beginning of the program until 1988, almost all program participants stayed in an off-property [[trailer park|mobile home park]] called '''Snow White Village Campground''' (the remainder in Lake Vista Village apartments) in nearby [[Kissimmee, Florida]]. 1987 saw the opening of Vista Way apartments, which were much closer to the participants' employment.<ref>{{Cite book|title=MKCP 10 Year Anniversary Newsletter: Summer of '87|first=Glenn|last=Mobley|publisher=Glenn Mobley and Robin Quick-Brantley|date=1998-04-27|page=3|accessdate=2009-03-08}}</ref> Following the resort's massive growth in the 1990s and the widespread popularity of the internet, the College Program has grown substantially, seeing three new participant housing complexes built and many more colleges represented. As of 2005, 8,000 students have participated each year, representing at least 301 colleges and universities<ref name=dailynebraskan/><ref name=msnbc>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/8464524/|title=Disney internships draw students, criticism|date=2005-07-05|author=Associated Press|publisher=msnbc.msn.com|accessdate=2009-03-05}}</ref> with an average of 4,000 students at any given time.<ref name=ofmouseandman>{{cite web|url=http://www.orlandoweekly.com/features/story.asp?id=12053|title=Of Mouse and Man|first=Jeffrey|last=Billman|date=2007-12-27|publisher=orlandoweekly.com|accessdate=2009-03-06}}</ref>
In the Autumn of 2004, student opportunities at [[Disneyland]] were combined with the opportunities available at Walt Disney World. The program was renamed to the '''Disney Theme Parks and Resorts College Program'''. Currently, the program is being promoted as, simply, the '''Disney College Program'''.
==Application process== There are specific requirements a student must meet before applying for the Disney College Program. All students must be of 18 years or older before the expected day of arrival. Students must be enrolled in an accredited university or college as a full-time or part-time student, and actively taking classes. Students may also participate in the semester immediately following graduation. Students must complete at least one semester of university or college before entering the Disney College Program, but can apply during their first semester for participation in the program during their second semester. In the case of schools with additional requirement criteria, a student must meet all of those eligibilities before being considered by the program.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cp.disneycareers.com/en/about-disney-college-program/overview/|title=Disney Application Requirements}}</ref>
Students who apply to the program are given the option of one of several program seasons throughout the year, each usually lasting between five and seven months, though the culinary session length is dependent upon the student's school schedule.
After the general application is filed, students may be selected to participate in a web-based interview. This can happen immediately or months later. Students who are selected to proceed beyond the web-based interview then go through a second round over the phone. Here the students clarify with recruiters which of the roles they would be receptive to while attending the program. Some of these roles (or positions) are food and beverage, attractions, custodial, hospitality, merchandise, and entertainment. If a student chooses to apply for an entertainment role, he or she must attend one of several regional auditions. At one point, there was a required viewing of a presentation, however, as of the Fall 2013 application period that is no longer a requirement.
Final notification of the applicant's status (accepted, pending, or no longer in consideration) is usually sent out about 3 weeks after the phone interview, but it can take several months.
==Program information== At the beginning of the program in the early 1980s, three "experiences" were emphasized: "The Learning Experience", which involved participation in Disney's "Leisure Time Business Management Studies", "The Work Experience" which included work in 4 major areas of the resort, and "The Recreational Experience" which emphasized recreational activities and Disney-sponsored events.<ref name=cpbrochure/> Since that time, the experiences have changed slightly to "living", "learning" and "earning".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wdwcollegeprogram.com/sap/its/mimes/zh_wdwcp/educators/program_info/cp_overview.html|title=Disney College Program Overview|publisher=''[[Disney]]''|accessdate=2009-03-05}}</ref>
The "Living" experience is similar to the original program's "Recreational" experience. Once the student has accepted their position with Disney, they can stay in one of four company sponsored housing units near Walt Disney World Resort during the duration of the program: Vista Way, Chatham Square, Patterson Court, and The Commons (which houses mainly international Cast Members). At the Disneyland Resort, participants stay in the Carnegie Plaza building approximately two miles north of the resort. Each participant can choose to live in a one, two, three, or four bedroom apartment with two to three people per bedroom.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://disney.go.com/disneycareers/disneycollegeprogram/dlr/students/housing/housing_overview.html|title=Working:A Unique Working Experience|publisher="[[Disney]]"|accessdate=2010-11-30}}</ref> In addition to these options, the Disneyland housing offers a limited number of studio-style apartments.
The cost of housing is deducted automatically from the student’s weekly salary. The cost of housing varies depending on the housing location. There are fees the student must pay upfront upon acceptance into the program based on housing, and these too vary between locations. In Florida there is a nonrefundable program assessment fee of $100 as well as a housing and administration fee for $200, which covers 2 weeks' rent. In California the program assessment fee is $100, with a refundable security deposit of $200 as well as $560 in housing and assessment fees which covers 4 weeks' rent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cp.disneycareers.com/en/program-components/living/fees/|title=Disney College Program Fees}}</ref>
Students are expected to follow certain guidelines in the housing complexes. Roommates are assigned by gender and age, except in the case of a married couple. If a student is under the age of 21 they automatically are placed in a “Wellness Apartment”, or one that is deemed alcohol-free. For students located in Florida, the Disney Company provides transportation to and from the theme parks. Transportation is not provided for students located in California. Those students are encouraged to bring their own cars. They are also given free bus passes for the [[OCTA]] public transportation system, and earn $1 each day the pass is used.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cp.disneycareers.com/en/program-components/living/policies/|title=Living Policies}}</ref>
The "Learning" experience began in the early 80s as a group of 9 seminars on the "philosophies and operating practices" of the various sections of their resort's business.<ref name=cpbrochure/> It has grown to include 8 different courses, each focusing on a Disney topic, rather than a business area. The Students are required to do textbook readings, write term papers and participate on projects. Additionally, there are now Disney Exploration Series courses, which are more focused on business areas as they relate to Disney. Participants, just like every Cast Member, attend Traditions, which is a 4 hour long orientation that demonstrates everything about the Resort of employment and the company in general.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wdwcollegeprogram.com/sap/its/mimes/zh_wdwcp/educators/program_info/education/education_overview.html|title=Education Overview|publisher=''[[Disney]]''|accessdate=2009-03-05}}</ref> The Disney Look is required for attendance at Traditions, which is the participants' first official day of work. The program also offers "job shadowing" for participants on days they are not working - the participant can follow Disney Cast Members whose careers are in fields similar to the student's major.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://media.www.dakotastudent.com/media/storage/paper970/news/2008/09/30/News/Disney.College.Program.Offers.Students.dynamic.Opportunities-3458260.shtml|title=Disney College Program offers students 'dynamic' opportunities|first=Brandi|last=Jewett|date=2008-09-30|publisher=dakotastudent.com|accessdate=2009-03-05}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><nowiki> Most of the courses are approved by the American Council on Education and offer participants the possibility to earn college credit during their program, subject to a decision by the participant's college or university.</nowiki><ref>{{cite web|url=http://disney.go.com/disneycareers/disneycollegeprogram/dlr/students/education/edu_overview.html|title=Education|publisher="[[Disney]]"|accessdate=2010-11-30}}</ref> The classes approved meet once a week, for most of the program (with breaks during peak seasons) and are four hours long.
The "Earning" experience consists of students working within their resort.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wdwcollegeprogram.com/sap/its/mimes/zh_wdwcp/educators/program_info/working/work_overview.html|title=Working: Real World Experience|publisher=''[[Disney]]''|accessdate=2009-03-05}}</ref> At the program's inception, students are expected to work in one of 4 "major operating areas": Food, Merchandise, Attractions, and Custodial.<ref name=cpbrochure/> Currently, Disney College Program students work in more than 20 different roles.
Depending on the requirements of a student's school, internship credit may be earned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://realvacationscheap.wordpress.com/2009/03/02/disney-college-program/|title=Disney College Program|date=2009-03-02|publisher=realvacationscheap.wordpress.com|accessdate=2009-03-05}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Walt Disney World International Program]]
==References== <references />
==External links== *[http://www.disneycollegeprogram.com Official Disney College Program website] *[http://corporate.disney.go.com/careers/students.html Other Disney student programs] *[http://dcpstory.com Stories About The Disney College Program] *[http://www.dcpparents.com Information for Parents of DCP Students]
[[Category:Walt Disney World|College Program]] [[Category:Internships]] [[Category:Disneyland]] [[Category:The Walt Disney Company]]

{{other uses}} {{primary sources|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox organization |name = English Program in Korea | image = EPIK (English Program in Korea) Logo.jpg |logo = |motto = |type = [[Teaching English as a foreign language]] |founded = 1995 |location = [[South Korea]] |homepage = http://www.epik.go.kr }} '''EPIK''' (''English Program in Korea'') is a program to improve the [[English language|English speaking]] abilities of students and teachers in [[Korea]], to foster cultural exchanges, and to reform English teaching methodologies in Korea. It is affiliated with the Korean Ministry of Education and is operated by the National Institute for International Education (NIIED). Established in 1995, EPIK encourages cross cultural exchange while promoting the development of English language competence for Korean students.<ref>{{cite web|title=EPIK Rationale|url=http://www.epik.go.kr/EPIK/html/about_epik/rationale.jsp|accessdate=22 April 2012}}</ref>
== History == Formally created in 1995 under the name KORETTA, EPIK has placed Guest English Teachers in Korean classrooms for over a decade. The program has undergone many administrative changes and is overseen by the NIIED. Currently, participants live and teach in 16 different Provinces and Metropolitan cities.<ref>http://www.epik.go.kr/EPIK/html/about_epik/timeline.jsp</ref>
== Organization== EPIK is overseen by NIIED, a division of the Korean Ministry of Education, Science and Technology (MEST). EPIK provides recruitment and Guest English Teacher support from a central office in [[Seoul]]. In conjunction with NIIED, Provincial Offices of Education offer assistance with various daily and work related affairs to Guest English Teachers. Participants can seek guidance from representatives at their Provincial Office of Education and from EPIK.
== References == <references />
==Further reading== *{{cite book|author=Mihyon Jeon|chapter=Globalization and South Korea's EPIK (English Program in Korea)|editor=Viniti Vaish|title=Globalization of Language and Culture in Asia: The Impact of Globalization Processes on Language|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QDeniyscslkC&pg=PA161|year=2010|publisher=A&C Black|isbn=978-1-84706-183-6|page=161}} *{{cite book|author1=Bernard Spolsky|author2=Kiwan Sung|title=Secondary School English Education in Asia: From Policy to Practice|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f6KsBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA51|date=27 March 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-64276-3|page=51}}
== External links == *[http://www.epik.go.kr/ EPIK webpage] *[https://twitter.com/EPIKprogram Official Twitter] *[https://www.youtube.com/EPIKprogram Official Youtube] *[http://www.facebook.com/EPIKprogram Official Facebook]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Epik}} [[Category:Education in South Korea]] [[Category:English-language education]]

{{BLP sources|date=February 2010}} {{Infobox person | image = | caption = | birth_date = 24 May 1960 | birth_place = [[Pemberton, New Jersey]] }} '''Jeff Celentano''' (born May 24, 1960), also credited as '''Jeff Weston''', is an American actor, screenwriter, producer and film director. Celentano starred as a character actor in such films as Robert Altman’s “[[The Player (film)|The Player]]”, ''[[American Ninja 2: The Confrontation]]'', ''[[Puppet Master II]]'', and ''[[Demonic Toys]]''. Also starring in “Dynasty” “Magnum P.I., and “Trapper John”. In 1994, he turned to directing with his first short film, ''Dickwad''. Which won several film festivals as best comedy short. He also directed ''[[Under the Hula Moon]]'', ''[[Gunshy (film)|Gunshy]]'' starring Diane Lane, “Breaking Point” starring Tom Berenger and Busta Rhymes. and most recently the boxing saga ''Glassjaw''. Celentano is an acting teacher and is the Executive Director of Drama at [[The Performer's Academy]] in [[Lake Forest, California]]. Celentano was born and raised in Pemberton, New Jersey.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Filmography (director)==
*''1994 - Dickwad *''1995 - Under The Hula Moon *''1997 - Elissa *''1998 - [[Gunshy (film)|Gunshy]] *''2000 - Primary Suspect *''2004 - Moscow Heat *''2007 - [[Say It in Russian]] *''2009 - [[Breaking Point (2009 film)|Breaking Point]] *''2014 - Echoes of Shannon Street (in development)
==External links== *{{IMDb name|0147985}} *[http://performersacademy.net/ The Performer’s Academy] *[http://jeffcelentano.com/ Official Site]
{{Authority control}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox scientist |name = Sir John Pringle, Bt |image =John Pringle.jpg |image_size =240px |caption = John Pringle |birth_date = 10 April 1707 |birth_place = [[Stitchel]], [[Roxburgh]], [[Scotland]][http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/476980/Sir-John-Pringle-1st-Baronet britannica.com: "Sir John Pringle 1st Baronet"] |death_date = {{d-da|18 January 1782|10 April 1707}} |death_place = [[London, England]], UK |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = [[Scotland|Scottish]] |ethnicity = |field = [[physician]] |work_institutions = |alma_mater = [[University of St Andrews]] |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = [[antiseptics]] |awards = [[Copley Medal]] (1752) |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = |signature = }} '''Sir John Pringle, 1st Baronet''', [[Presidents of the Royal Society|PRS]] (10 April 1707 – 18 January 1782) was a [[Kingdom of Great Britain|British]] [[physician]] who has been called the "father of military medicine" (although [[Ambroise Paré]] and [[Jonathan Letterman]] have also been accorded this [[sobriquet]]). ==Biography== ===Youth and early career=== John Pringle was the youngest son of [[Sir John Pringle, 2nd Baronet]], of [[Stichill]], [[Roxburghshire]] (1662–1721), by his spouse Magdalen (d. December 1739), daughter of [[Sir Gilbert Eliott, 3rd Baronet, of Stobs]]. He was educated at [[St Andrews University|St Andrews]], at [[Edinburgh University|Edinburgh]], and at [[Leiden University|Leiden]]. In 1730 he graduated with a degree of Doctor of Physic at the last-named university, where he was an intimate friend of [[Gerard van Swieten]] and [[Albrecht von Haller]]. He settled in [[Edinburgh]] at first as a physician, but between 1733 and 1744 was also Professor of Moral Philosophy at Edinburgh University. In 1742 he became physician to the [[John Dalrymple, 2nd Earl of Stair|Earl of Stair]], then commanding the British army in [[Flanders]]. About the time of the [[battle of Dettingen]] in Bavaria in June 1743, when the British army was encamped at [[Aschaffenburg]], Pringle, through the Earl of Stair, brought about an agreement with the [[Adrien Maurice de Noailles|Marshal of Noailles]], the French commander, that military hospitals on both sides be considered as neutral, immune sanctuaries for the sick and wounded, and should be mutually protected. The [[International Red Cross]], as constituted by the modern [[Geneva Conventions]],"Article 1. Ambulances and military hospitals shall be recognized as neutral, and as such, protected and respected by the belligerents as long as they accommodate wounded and sick. Neutrality shall end if the said ambulances or hospitals should be held by a military force." [https://ihl-databases.icrc.org/applic/ihl/ihl.nsf/Article.xsp?action=openDocument&documentId=1A60DC7BD5ED4FB6C12563CD00515301 Article 1 of the ''Convention for the Amelioration of the Condition of the Wounded in Armies in the Field. Geneva, 22 August 1864'']. developed from this conception and agreement.[http://history.amedd.army.mil/booksdocs/misc/evprev/ch2.htm The Evolution of Preventive Medicine in the United States Army 1607–1939: The Colonial Period (1607–1775)] In 1744 he was appointed by the [[Prince William Augustus, Duke of Cumberland|Duke of Cumberland]] physician-general to the forces in the [[Low Countries]]. In 1749, having settled in a smart house in [[Pall Mall, London|Pall Mall]], [[London]], he was made [[physician in ordinary]] to the [[Duke of Cumberland]]. On 1 April 1752 he married Charlotte (d. Dec 1753) second daughter of Dr [[William Oliver (physician)|William Oliver]] (1695–1764) of [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]], the inventor of [[Bath Oliver]] biscuits, but they had no issue. In 1760, he wrote an appreciation of the Life of General [[James Wolfe]].{{cite book|last=Pringle|first=John (Bt)|url=http://eco.canadiana.ca/view/oocihm.20293/3?r=0&s=1|title= Life of General James Wolfe, the conqueror of Canada, or, The elogium of that renowned hero : attempted according to the rules of eloquence with a monumental inscription Latin and English to perpetuate his memory|location=London|year=1760|pages=36}} On 5 June 1766 John Pringle was created a baronet, and in 1774 he was appointed Physician to His Majesty King [[George III]]. He was also a frequent travelling companion to [[Benjamin Franklin]]. The successful London bookseller [[Andrew Millar]] noted Pringle and Franklin as dinner guests at his home.{{Cite web|url=http://www.millar-project.ed.ac.uk/manuscripts/html_output/1.html|title=The manuscripts, Letter from Andrew Millar to Andrew Mitchell, 26 August, 1766. Andrew Millar Project. University of Edinburgh.|website=www.millar-project.ed.ac.uk|access-date=2016-06-02}} ===Academia=== His first book, ''Observations on the Nature and Cure of Hospital and Jayl Fevers'', was published in 1750, and in the same year he contributed to the ''Philosophical Transactions'' of the [[Royal Society]] three papers on ''Experiments on Septic and Antiseptic Substances'', which gained him the [[Copley Medal]]. Two years later he published his important work, ''Observations on the Diseases of the Army in Camp and Garrison'', which entitles him to be regarded as the founder of modern [[military medicine]]. In November 1772 he was elected [[President of the Royal Society]], a position he held until 1778. In this capacity he delivered six discourses, which were afterwards collected into a single volume (1783). In 1735, Pringle became a Fellow of the [[Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh]]. Pringle was a regular correspondent and friend of [[James Burnett, Lord Monboddo]], the Scottish philosopher. Monboddo was an important thinker in pre-evolutionary theory, and some scholars actually credit him with the concept of [[evolution]]; however, Monboddo was also quite eccentric, which was one reason for Monboddo's not receiving credit for the evolution concepts. It was in a letter to Pringle in 1773 that Monboddo revealed he did not really hold to a belief of men being born with tails, which was the chief point of his ridicule.Letter from Lord Monboddo to Sir John Pringle, 16 June 1773; reprinted by William Knight 1900 {{ISBN|1-85506-207-0}} At the age of 73 he went, briefly, to Edinburgh in 1780, but returned to London in September 1781, and died in the following year. ==Legacy== There is a monument to Pringle in [[Westminster Abbey]], executed by [[Joseph Nollekens]]. At Sir John's death his baronetcy became extinct. After a legal case in 2004, the [[Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh]] was able to open the Pringle papers it holds to the public.{{cite news |author= |title= Historic manuscripts on display|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/4007407.stm|newspaper= [[BBC News]] |date= 13 Nov 2004 }} ==See also== {{wikisource author}} *[[Clan Pringle]] *[[Pringle baronets]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} *{{EB1911|wstitle=Pringle, Sir John}} ==Further reading== {{refbegin}} *{{Citation | pmid=5330009 | last=Selwyn | first=S | publication-date=July 1966| year=1966 | title=Sir John Pringle: hospital reformer, moral philosopher and pioneer of antiseptics | volume=10 | issue=3 | periodical=Medical History | pages=266–74 | pmc=1033606 | doi=10.1017/s0025727300011133}} *{{Citation | pmid=14348441 | last=Hamilton| first=D | publication-date=June 1965| year=1965 | title=Sir John Pringle (1707–1782), Military Physician and Hygienist | volume=38 | issue= | periodical=Revue internationale des services de santé des armées de terre, de mer et de l'air | pages=497–8}} *{{Citation | pmid=14205667 | publication-date=Nov 30, 1964 | year=1964 | title=Sir John Pringle (1707–1782), Military Physician and Hygienist | volume=190 | issue= | periodical=[[Journal of the American Medical Association|JAMA]] | pages=849–50|doi=10.1001/jama.1964.03070220055019 }} *{{Citation | pmid=14189958 | last=Hamilton| first=D | publication-date=1964 | year=1964 | title=Sir John Pringle | volume=110 | issue= | periodical=Journal of the Royal Army Medical Corps | pages=138–47}} *{{Cite DNB|wstitle= Pringle, John|volume = 46|pages = 386–8}} *{{Cite NIE|wstitle= Pringle, John|short=x}} * ''Extinct and Dormant Baronetcies of England, Ireland, and Scotland'', by Messrs. John and John Bernard Burke, 2nd edition, London, 1841, p. 428. * ''Burke's Peerage, Baronetage & Knightage'', edited by Peter Townend, London, 1970, 105th edition, p. 2186. {{refend}} ==External links== *[http://www.clanpringle.org.uk ClanPringle.org.uk] {{s-start}} {{s-reg|gb-bt}} {{s-new}} {{s-ttl | title=[[Pringle Baronets|Baronet]]
'''(of Pall Mall)''' | years=1766–1782 }} {{s-non | reason=Extinct}} {{s-end}} {{Royal Society presidents 1700s}} {{Copley Medallists 1751-1800}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pringle, John}} [[Category:1707 births]] [[Category:1782 deaths]] [[Category:18th-century Scottish medical doctors]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of St Andrews]] [[Category:British Army personnel of the War of the Austrian Succession]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]] [[Category:Leiden University alumni]] [[Category:Members of the Philosophical Society of Edinburgh]] [[Category:People from the Scottish Borders]] [[Category:Philosophy academics]] [[Category:Philosophy teachers]] [[Category:Physicians-in-Ordinary]] [[Category:Recipients of the Copley Medal]] [[Category:Scottish military medical officers]] [[Category:Younger sons of baronets]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Edinburgh|Pringle, John, 1st Baronet]] [[Category:Scottish non-fiction writers|Pringle, John, 1st Baronet]] [[Category:Baronets in the Baronetage of Great Britain|Pringle, Sir John, 1st Baronet]] [[Category:Presidents of the Royal Society|Pringle, Sir John, 1st Baronet]]

revision.text:
{{No footnotes|date=February 2008}} '''Joyce Dattner''' is a [[United States|U.S.]] [[life coach]] and works and resides in [[San Francisco]], [[California]]. Dattner was one of the six Vice Presidential candidates of the [[New Alliance Party]] and its candidate [[Lenora Fulani]] in the [[United States presidential election, 1988|1988 presidential election]] [http://www.uselectionatlas.org/RESULTS/national.php?year=1988&minper=0&f=1&off=0&elect=0]. In that election, she and Fulani became the first women to achieve [[ballot access]] in all 50 states.
==Coaching==
Joyce Dattner is a life performance coach who believes that emotional, social and intellectual development is key to succeeding in life and in work. For twenty years, she has been helping individuals and groups reinitiate their capacity to grow into new careers and leadership positions.
As a coach, Joyce Dattner takes "life performance" literally—helping people see living as an evolving, creative act, and themselves as performers of more effective and satisfying ways of being in the world. Her clients learn the skills of improvising to produce qualitative change in how they relate to themselves, their colleagues and loved ones. Specializing in personal and professional coaching in individual and group environments, Joyce helps clients grow to meet difficult career challenges—negotiating transitions from manager to executive or from employee to entrepreneur, navigating office politics, and handling diversity issues in the workplace.
Joyce Dattner founded and directs the [http://www.lifeperformancecoaching.com West Coast Center for Life Performance Coaching]. There she leads a training program for teachers, doctors, social workers, coaches, counselors and therapists in her performance-based approach to human development. In addition, she conducts long and short term training for community-based organizations throughout [[California]].
She has never been satisfied with accepting things as they are. As a young teacher in the 1970s she left a career in the [[New York City Public Schools]] system to search for more innovative approaches to learning and development. What she found was the groundbreaking discoveries of [[Fred Newman (philosopher)|Fred Newman]], founder of [[social therapy]], and [[Lois Holzman]], [[developmental psychologist]], who together created a unique performance-based approach to human development.
Driven by her commitment to helping people change themselves — and in the process, change the world — Joyce Dattner has become a leading practitioner of Newman and Holzman's approach, now used in youth development programs, private and public mental health centers, alternative school initiatives, and agencies and organizations servicing diverse populations in varied settings—from [[New York City]] to [[Los Angeles]] to [[Johannesburg]].
In addition to her coaching and training work in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]], Joyce Dattner has traveled the globe serving as a faculty member of the [http://www.eastsideinstitute.org East Side Institute for Group and Short Term Psychotherapy] and working with [[Fortune 500]] companies as a senior trainer with the consulting firm, [http://www.performanceofalifetime.com Performance of a Lifetime (POAL)] in [[New York City]]. In [[Taiwan]] she trained the faculty and staff of non-governmental organizations, including [[community activists]], [[trade union]] organizers, [[teacher]]s, and [[sex workers]]. She's coached [[psychologists]], [[social workers]], and [[teacher]]s working with children and adults living in [[refugee]] centers in the former [[Yugoslavia]]. Most recently, in July 2006, Joyce Dattner travelled to [[Brazil]] and [[Argentina]] to work with teachers and students at the university-level to advance their work with youth utilizing the performance approach to development and building community.
==Cultural==
Joyce Dattner is the founder and president of the [http://www.bacic.org Bay Area Center for Independent Culture (BACIC)], is a non-partisan, 501(c)(3) non-profit organization dedicated to promoting human development through the use of an innovative performance and development based model. The non profit creates outside of school, educational and performing arts activities for hundreds of young people living in some of the Bay Area's poorest communities. BACIC sponsors community and experimental theatre, develop leadership training and pursue volunteer initiatives that build and strengthen communities. Programs produced by BACIC include the [https://web.archive.org/web/20070805004336/http://www.bacic.org/bayareaallstars.html Bay Area All Stars Talent Show Network] and the [https://web.archive.org/web/20070805004921/http://www.bacic.org/dct.html Developing Community Theatre].
==Politics==
Joyce Dattner, co-founder and Chair of [http://www.independentvoice.org IndependentVoice], a political [[non-profit]] 501(c)(4) organization, has played a leading role in the creation of cultural, educational, therapeutic and political initiatives concerned with human growth, democracy and development for the past three decades, including the country's largest anti-violence youth program, the [http://www.allstars.org All Stars Talent Show Network].
Joyce Dattner was one of the six [[United States Vice President|Vice Presidential]] candidates of the [[New Alliance Party]] (NAP) in the [[United States presidential election, 1988|1988 presidential election]]. The vice presidential candidates varied from state to state, but all were the running mates of [[Lenora Fulani]]. As a life coach, Dattner believes in the approaches of Fred Newman and [[Lois Holzman]], the former of whom was also the founder of the NAP. In 1985 she had been a midwest coordinator for the party and a member of Fulani and Newman's "Rainbow Alliance."
Dattner was the chair of the [[San Francisco, California]] chapter of the [[Reform Party of the United States of America]]. Also, a president of the New York City Unemployed and Welfare Council in the 1970s and had run unsuccessfully for the [[New York State Assembly]].
==References== * [http://www.allstars.org All Stars Project, Inc.] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060110134706/http://www.appliedimprov.net/conference/dattner.htm Applied Improvisation Network, Profile: Joyce Dattner] * [http://www.bacic.org Bay Area Center for Independent Culture] * [http://www.eastsideinstitute.org/ East Side Institute for Group and Short Term Psychotherapy] * [http://www.performingtheworld.org/ Performing the World] * [http://www.socialtherapygroup.com/ The Social Therapy Group] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060815001644/http://www.lifeperformancecoaching.com/joycedattner.html West Coast Center for Life Performance Coaching: Joyce Dattner Bio] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060831025230/http://www.westcoastcenter.com/staff.html West Coast Center for Social Therapy: Joyce Dattner Bio] * [http://www.independentvoice.org IndependentVoice.Org] * [http://www.sfweekly.com/issues/1999-08-11/music4_2.html Athitakis, Mark "Booty Call" ''SF Weekly'' Aug 11, 1999] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060208084931/http://www.bostonphoenix.com/boston/news_features/talking_politics/documents/03521598.asp Reilly, Adam "ChIP off the old block" ''The Boston Phoenix'' January 27, 2004 ]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dattner, Joyce}} [[Category:United States vice-presidential candidates, 1988]] [[Category:20th-century American politicians]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:New Alliance Party (United States) politicians]] [[Category:Female United States vice-presidential candidates]] [[Category:Life coaches]] [[Category:Reform Party of the United States of America politicians]] [[Category:20th-century American women politicians]]

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{more citations needed|date=April 2012}} {{Essay-like|date=December 2007}} }} {{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:Japanese words and phrases]]}} [[File:LECOffice.jpg|thumb|right|LEC, one cram school company in Japan]] [[File:Yoyogi Seminer Nagoya.JPG|thumb|right|The Nagoya office of Yoyogi Seminar]] '''''Gakushū juku''''' ({{lang-ja|[[wiktionary:学習塾|学習塾]]}}; see [[cram school]]) are private, fee-paying schools that offer supplementary classes often in preparation for key school and university entrance exams. The term is primarily used to characterize such schools in [[Japan]]. Juku’s typically operate after regular school hours, on weekends, and during school vacations. ==History== Juku attendance rose from the 1970s through the mid-1980s; participation rates increased at every grade level throughout the [[compulsory education]] years. This phenomenon was a source of great concern to the [[Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (Japan)|Ministry of Education]], which issued directives to the regular schools that it hoped would reduce the need for after-school lessons, but these directives had little practical effect. Some juku have branches in the [[United States]] and other countries to help children living abroad catch up with students in Japan. While new media have been introduced into juku as instructional and delivery methods, traditional teaching is increasingly shifting to individual [[tutor]]ing. This shift is partly a response by the supplementary education industry to [[Demographics of Japan|declining numbers of children]] in Japan and the threat this decline poses to their industry. ==Structure and curriculum== There are two types of juku, academic and nonacademic. ===Academic juku=== Academic juku can be roughly divided into categories. * Locally based middle- or small-sized cram schools{{cite web|url=http://www.education-in-japan.info/sub109.html|title=education-in-japan.info|publisher=|accessdate=9 April 2016}} * Schools for salvaging dropouts or children who avoid regular school (free schools, etc.) * Franchising cram schools * Other miscellaneous types of cram schools As of 2011, almost one in five children in their first year of [[primary school]] attended after-class instruction, rising to nearly all university-bound high schoolers.{{cite web|url=http://www.economist.com/node/21542222|title=Testing times|work=The Economist|accessdate=9 April 2016}} The fees are around ¥260,000 ($3,300) annually. Academic juku offer instruction in the five required subjects: [[mathematics]], [[Japanese language]], [[science]], [[English language|English]], and [[social studies]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mext.go.jp/b_menu/shingi/chukyo/chukyo3/016/siryo/04092801/003/002.htm|title=中央教育審議会初等中等教育分科会教育課程部会教育課程企画特別部会（第２回）|publisher=|accessdate=9 April 2016}} They are best known and most widely publicized for their role as "cram schools", where children (sent by concerned parents) can study to improve scores on upper-secondary school [[entrance examination]]s. However, as seen above, there are also juku that provide supplementary education, whether remedial courses to help children falling behind in their studies, refresher courses to explain material in further detail, or courses that cover material on a higher level and thus appeal to children bored by the standardized class structure.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/04/27/world/how-do-japan-s-students-do-it-they-cram.html|title=How Do Japan's Students Do It? They Cram|date=27 April 1992|work=The New York Times|accessdate=9 April 2016}} ===Nonacademic juku=== Many other children, particularly younger children, attend nonacademic juku for [[piano]] lessons, [[art]] instruction, [[human swimming|swimming]], and abacus ([[soroban]]) lessons. ==Social influence== Juku also play a social role, and children in Japan say they like going to juku because they are able to make new friends. Many children ask to be sent because their friends attend. Some children seem to like juku because of the closer personal contact they have with their teachers and, for students in crowded spaces like Tokyo in particular, the relief jukus can provide from small homes, family, television, Internet, and other distractions. To some observers, juku represent an attempt by parents to exercise a meaningful measure of choice in [[Education in Japan|Japanese education]], particularly for children attending [[Public school (government funded)|public schools]]. ==Controversy== ===Criticism=== Because of the commercial nature of most juku, some critics argue that they have [[profit (economics)|profit]] rather than [[education]] at heart. Shares in five juku chains are traded publicly, and 25 others were as of 1992 ready to issue stock as well. Not all students can afford to attend juku, but school and university test scores rise in direct proportion to spending on juku. The average fee is $160 a month for elementary school and $175 a month for junior high school, but the best ones are several times that amount. Japan spent $10.9 billion on tutoring and cram schools in 1991 alone, including $9 billion on juku for students in the ninth grade or below "almost double the figure spent [in 1985]." With poor students therefore at risk of falling behind, the social and economic [[economic inequality|inequality]] in what had been a relatively [[egalitarian]] approach to education, at least in public schools through ninth grade, is why Japan's powerful teachers' union does not support the juku institution. In response to these accusations,
"juku teachers and administrators say that since their schools are profit-making enterprises, they have to guarantee results to succeed. The results are easy to measure since they depend on how many graduates pass the examinations for private school. The profit motive, in other words, provides an incentive to create an atmosphere in which students want to learn."
"The rise of juku is praised as a secret of Japanese success, a healthy reflection of a system of advancement based on merit. It is also criticized as forcing a new generation to surrender its [[childhood]] out of an obsession with status and [[rat race|getting ahead]]. 'Juku are harmful to Japanese education and to children,' said Ikuo Amano, professor of sociology at the University of Tokyo. 'It's not healthy for kids to have so little free time. It is not healthy to become completely caught up in competition and status at such a young age.'"
For some, "the schools are also seen as reinforcing a tradition of rote learning over ingenuity." ===Merits=== In many ways, juku compensate for the formal education system's inability or unwillingness to address particular individual problems. "In a 2008 government survey, two-thirds of parents attributed the growing role of juku to shortcomings in public education," such as the abolition of Saturday schooling (which therefore reduces the number of hours available to cover course material) and the reduction of curricular content (see [[Yutori education]]). Juku offer a more personalized service "and many encourage individual inquisitiveness when the public system treats everyone alike. 'The juku are succeeding in ways that the schools are not,' an OECD report says." ==See also== *[[Higher education in Japan]] *[[Kyoiku mama]] *[[List of Jukus in Japan|List of Juku in Japan]] * [[Yobiko]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/jptoc.html Library of Congress entry] {{commons category|Cram schools in Japan}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Academic pressure in East Asian culture]] [[Category:School types]] [[Category:Testing and exams in Japan]] [[Category:Test preparation companies]]

revision.text:
This is a '''list of Head Masters of [[Eton College]]''' since 1442. Note: for explanation of alternative year dates in this list, such as "1494/5", see [[Old Style and New Style dates]]. ==List== ===15th century=== #William Westbury (1442–1447){{efn|[[William Waynflete]] was traditionally reckoned as the first Head Master of Eton, serving for a brief period preceding Westbury in 1442, but modern scholarship does not support this claim. Waynflete did, however, become Provost of the college shortly afterwards.{{cite book|last=Davis|first=Virginia|title=William Waynflete, Bishop and Educationalist|page=37|year=1993|place=Woodbridge|publisher=The Boydell Press|ISBN=0851153496}}}} #Richard Hopton (1447–1453) #Thomas Forster (1453) #Clement Smith (1453–1458) #John Peyntor (1458–1467) #Clement Smyth (1467–1470) #Walter Barber (1470 – {{circa}} 1479) #David Haubroke ({{circa}} 1479 – 1484) #Thomas Mache (1484–1485/6) #[[William Horman]] (1485/6–1494/5) #Edward Powell (1494/5–1496) ===16th century=== {{ordered list|start=12 | Nicholas Bradbryg (1496–1501) | Robert Yong (1501–1502/3) | John Smyth (1502/3–1507) | John Goldyve (1507–1510) | Thomas Phylips (1510–1511) | Thomas Erlysman (1511–1515) | Robert Aldrich (1515–1521) | Thomas White (1521–1524) | John Goldwyn (1524–1528) | [[Richard Cox (bishop)|Richard Cox]] (1528–1534) | [[Nicholas Udall]] (1534–1541/2) | ? Smyth (1541/2–1544/5) | Robert Cater (1544/5–1547) | William Barker (1547–1555) | ''Unknown'' (1555 – {{circa}} 1560){{efn|name=Brock_Malim|Clutton-Brock begins Malim's term in 1555.{{cite book|first=Arthur|last=Clutton-Brock|title=Eton|year=1900|place=London|publisher=George Bell and Sons|page=242|isbn=9781164638483}}}} | William Malim ({{circa}} 1560– {{circa}} 1563){{efn|name=Brock_Malim}} | William Smyth ({{circa}} 1563 – {{circa}} 1571) | Reuben Sherwood ({{circa}} 1571 – 1579)
[[Hugh Blythe]] ({{circa}} 1579?){{efn|Blythe is listed by Clutton-Brock, but not included in the school's official list.}} | Thomas Ridley (1579–1583) | John Hammond (1583–1594) }} ===17th century=== {{ordered list|start=32 | [[Richard Langley (priest)|Richard Langley]] (1594–1611) | Richard Wright (1611) | Matthew Bust (1611–1630) | John Harrison (1630–1636) | William Norris (1636 – {{circa}} 1646) | Nicholas Gray ({{circa}} 1646 – 1648) | George Goad (1648) | Thomas Horne (1648–1654) | John Boncle (1654–1655) | Thomas Singleton (1655–1660) | Thomas Mountague (1660–1671) | [[John Rosewell (headmaster)|John Rosewell]] (1671–1682) | Charles Roderick (1682–1690) }} ===18th century=== {{ordered list|start=45 | John Newborough (1690–1711) | [[Andrew Snape]] (1711–1720) | [[Henry Bland]] (1720–1728) | [[William George (dean)|William George]] (1728–1743) | [[William Cooke (Provost of King's College)|William Cooke]] (1743–1745) | [[John Sumner (priest)|John Sumner]] (1745–1754) | [[Edward Barnard (provost)|Edward Barnard]] (1754–1765) | [[John Foster (canon)|John Foster]] (1765–1773) | [[Jonathan Davies (English priest)|Jonathan Davies]] (1773–1792) }} ===19th century=== {{ordered list|start=54 | [[George Heath (priest)|George Heath]] (1792–1802) | [[Joseph Goodall]] (1802–1809) | [[John Keate]] (1809–1834) | [[Edward Craven Hawtrey]] (1834–1853) | [[Charles Old Goodford]] (1853–1862) | [[Edward Balston]] (1862–1868) | [[James John Hornby]] (1868–1884) }} ===20th century=== {{ordered list|start=61 | [[Edmond Warre]] (1884–1905) | [[Edward Lyttelton]] (1905–1916) | [[Cyril Alington]] (1916–1933) | [[Claude Aurelius Elliott]] (1933–1949) | [[Robert Birley]] (1949–1964) | [[Anthony Chenevix-Trench]] (1964–1970) | [[Michael McCrum]] (1970–1980) | [[William Eric Kinloch Anderson|Eric Anderson]] (1980–1994) }} ===21st century=== {{ordered list|start=69 | [[John Lewis (headmaster)|John Lewis]] (1994–2002) | [[Anthony R M Little|Tony Little]] (2002–2015) | [[Simon Henderson (headmaster)|Simon Henderson]] (2015–present) }} ==See also== * [[List of Provosts of Eton College]] * [[Master in College]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist}} ===Sources=== {{refbegin}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.etoncollege.com/HeadMasters.aspx|title=Head Masters of Eton since 1442|publisher=Eton College|accessdate=20 March 2016}} {{refend}} {{Eton Head Masters|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Lists of people by employer|Eton College, Head Masters]] [[Category:Lists of educators|Eton College, Head Masters]] [[Category:Lists of people associated with Eton College|Head Masters]] [[Category:Head Masters of Eton College| ]]

revision.text:
[[File:State_Library_at_Night.jpg|thumb|[[State Library of Victoria]]]] This is a list of '''libraries in Melbourne''', Victoria, Australia, the second [[UNESCO]] [[City of Literature]].<ref>[http://www.cityofliterature.com/ecol.aspx?sec=8&pid=38 International: Cities of Literature] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081229045638/http://www.cityofliterature.com/ecol.aspx?sec=8&pid=38 |date=2008-12-29 }}</ref> Melbourne has a rich and varied books-and-reading culture and municipal councils throughout Melbourne provide funding and support for a rich network of libraries. Membership of these libraries is free. [[File:Melbourne Athenaeum.jpg|thumb|Melbourne Athenaeum]]
== Community / Non-profit libraries == *[[Australian Lesbian and Gay Archives]] *Berwick Mechanics' Institute *Footscray Mechanics' Institute Inc. Library, [[Footscray, Victoria|Footscray]] *[[Athenaeum, Melbourne|Melbourne Athenaeum Library]] *[[Prahran Mechanics' Institute]]
==Local Government libraries== Melbourne's public library services are operated by local government municipalities through a range of grants funding and service agreements. In addition to branch libraries a number of library service providers also operate a mobile service to outer Metropolitan areas.
'''Inner City''' [[File:East Melbourne Library August 2016.jpg|thumb|upright|The interior of East Melbourne Library]] * The [[City of Melbourne]] has libraries in [[Melbourne City Centre|Melbourne]], [[Docklands, Victoria|Docklands]], [[East Melbourne, Victoria|East Melbourne]] and [[North Melbourne, Victoria|North Melbourne]].<ref>[http://librarysearch.melbourne.vic.gov.au/opac/ Melbourne library service] {{webarchive|url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20090519091612/http://librarysearch.melbourne.vic.gov.au/opac/ |date=2009-05-19 }}</ref> * The [[City of Port Phillip]] has libraries in [[Albert Park, Victoria|Albert Park]], [[South Melbourne, Victoria|Emerald Hill]], [[Middle Park, Victoria|Middle Park]], [[Port Melbourne, Victoria|Port Melbourne]] and [[St Kilda, Victoria|St Kilda]].<ref>[http://www.portphillip.vic.gov.au/library.html Port Phillip Library Services] {{webarchive|url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20090518203421/http://www.portphillip.vic.gov.au/library.html |date=2009-05-18 }}</ref> * The [[City of Yarra]] has libraries in [[Carlton North, Victoria|Carlton North]], [[Collingwood, Victoria|Collingwood]], [[Fitzroy, Victoria|Fitzroy]], [[Fitzroy North, Victoria|Fitzroy North]] and [[Richmond, Victoria|Richmond]].<ref>[http://www.yarracity.vic.gov.au/Library/ Yarra Libraries]</ref>
'''Northern suburbs''' * The [[City of Banyule]] has libraries in [[Ivanhoe, Victoria|Ivanhoe]], [[Rosanna, Victoria|Rosanna]] and [[Watsonia, Victoria|Watsonia]].<ref name="YPRL">[http://www.yprl.vic.gov.au/ Yarra Plenty regional library]</ref> * The [[City of Darebin]] has libraries in [[Fairfield, Victoria|Fairfield]], [[Northcote, Victoria|Northcote]], [[Preston, Victoria|Preston]] and [[Reservoir, Victoria|Reservoir]].<ref>[http://www.darebin-libraries.vic.gov.au/ Darebin libraries]</ref> * The [[City of Hume]] has libraries in [[Broadmeadows, Victoria|Broadmeadows]], [[Craigieburn, Victoria|Craigieburn]], [[Gladstone Park, Victoria|Gladstone Park]], [[Sunbury, Victoria|Sunbury]] and [[Tullamarine, Victoria|Tullamarine]].<ref>[http://www.humelibraries.vic.gov.au/ Hume libraries]</ref> * The [[City of Moonee Valley]] has libraries in [[Ascot Vale, Victoria|Ascot Vale]], [[Avondale Heights, Victoria|Avondale Heights]], [[Flemington, Victoria|Flemington]], [[Moonee Ponds, Victoria|Moonee Ponds]] and [[Niddrie, Victoria|Niddrie]].<ref>[http://www.mvcc.vic.gov.au/Page/Page.asp?Page_Id=185&h=1&p=1 Moonee Valley libraries] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090518202001/http://www.mvcc.vic.gov.au/Page/Page.asp?Page_Id=185&h=1&p=1 |date=2009-05-18 }}</ref> * The [[City of Moreland]] has libraries in [[Brunswick, Victoria|Brunswick]], [[Brunswick West, Victoria|Brunswick West]], [[Coburg, Victoria|Coburg]], [[Fawkner, Victoria|Fawkner]] and [[Glenroy, Victoria|Glenroy]].<ref>[http://www.moreland.vic.gov.au/moreland-libraries.html Moreland libraries]</ref> * The [[Shire of Nillumbik]] has libraries in [[Greensborough, Victoria|Greensborough]] and [[Eltham, Victoria|Eltham]].<ref name="YPRL"/> * The [[City of Whittlesea]] has libraries in [[Lalor, Victoria|Lalor]], [[Mill Park, Victoria|Mill Park]], [[Thomastown, Victoria|Thomastown]] and [[Whittlesea, Victoria|Whittlesea]].<ref name="YPRL"/>
'''Eastern suburbs''' * The [[City of Boroondara]] has libraries in [[Ashburton, Victoria|Ashburton]], [[Balwyn, Victoria|Balwyn]], [[Camberwell, Victoria|Camberwell]], [[Hawthorn, Victoria|Hawthorn]] and [[Kew, Victoria|Kew]].<ref>[http://www.boroondara.vic.gov.au/leisure/library Boroondara libraries]</ref> * The [[City of Knox]] has libraries in [[Wantirna South, Victoria|Wantirna South]], [[Boronia, Victoria|Boronia]], [[Ferntree Gully, Victoria|Ferntree Gully]] and [[Rowville, Victoria|Rowville]].<ref name="ERL">[http://www.erl.vic.gov.au/ Eastern Regional libraries]</ref> * The [[City of Manningham]] has libraries in [[Bulleen, Victoria|Bulleen]], [[Doncaster, Victoria|Doncaster]], [[Doncaster East, Victoria|Doncaster East]] and [[Warrandyte, Victoria|Warrandyte]].<ref name="WMRL">[http://www.wev.vic.gov.au/ Whitehorse Manningham Regional Library Corporation]</ref> * The [[City of Maroondah]] has libraries in [[Croydon, Victoria|Croydon]] and [[Ringwood, Victoria|Ringwood]].<ref name="ERL"/> * The [[City of Whitehorse]] has libraries in [[Blackburn, Victoria|Blackburn]], [[Box Hill, Victoria|Box Hill]], [[Nunawading, Victoria|Nunawading]] and [[Vermont South, Victoria|Vermont South]].<ref name="WMRL"/> * The [[Shire of Yarra Ranges]] has libraries in [[Belgrave, Victoria|Belgrave]], [[Healesville, Victoria|Healesville]], [[Lilydale, Victoria|Lilydale]], [[Montrose, Victoria|Montrose]], [[Mooroolbark, Victoria|Mooroolbark]], [[Mount Evelyn, Victoria|Mount Evelyn]] and [[Yarra Junction, Victoria|Yarra Junction]].<ref name="ERL"/>
'''South Eastern suburbs''' * The [[City of Bayside]] has libraries in [[Beaumaris, Victoria|Beaumaris]], [[Brighton, Victoria|Brighton]], [[Hampton, Victoria|Hampton]] and [[Sandringham, Victoria|Sandringham]].<ref>[http://www.bayside.vic.gov.au/library.htm Bayside Library Service]</ref> * The [[Shire of Cardinia]] has libraries in [[Emerald, Victoria|Emerald]] and [[Pakenham, Victoria|Pakenham]].<ref name="CCLC">[http://www.cclc.vic.gov.au/ Casey Cardinia Library Corporation]</ref> * The [[City of Casey]] has libraries in [[Cranbourne, Victoria|Cranbourne]], [[Doveton, Victoria|Doveton]], [[Endeavour Hills, Victoria|Endeavour Hills]], [[Hampton Park, Victoria|Hampton Park]] and [[Narre Warren, Victoria|Narre Warren]] <ref name="CCLC"/> * The [[City of Greater Dandenong]] has libraries in [[Springvale, Victoria|Springvale]] and [[Dandenong, Victoria|Dandenong]].<ref>[http://www.greaterdandenong.com/Documents.asp?ID=1460&Title=Library+Services Greater Dandenong Library Services]</ref> * The [[City of Frankston]] has libraries in [[Frankston, Victoria|Frankston]] and [[Carrum Downs, Victoria|Carrum Downs]].<ref>[http://www.frankston.vic.gov.au/Library/index.aspx Frankston Library Service] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090518200247/http://www.frankston.vic.gov.au/Library/index.aspx |date=2009-05-18 }}</ref> * The [[City of Glen Eira]] has libraries in [[Bentleigh, Victoria|Bentleigh]], [[Carnegie, Victoria|Carnegie]], [[Caulfield, Victoria|Caulfield]] and [[Elsternwick, Victoria|Elsternwick]].<ref>[http://library.gleneira.vic.gov.au/cgi-bin/spydus.exe/MSGTRN/OPAC/HOME Glen Eira Library Service] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090609154846/http://library.gleneira.vic.gov.au/cgi-bin/spydus.exe/MSGTRN/OPAC/HOME |date=2009-06-09 }}</ref> * The [[City of Kingston]] has libraries in [[Chelsea, Victoria|Chelsea]], [[Cheltenham, Victoria|Cheltenham]], [[Clarinda, Victoria|Clarinda]], [[Dingley Village, Victoria|Dingley Village]], [[Highett, Victoria|Highett]], [[Moorabbin, Victoria|Moorabbin]], [[Parkdale, Victoria|Parkdale]] and [[Patterson Lakes, Victoria|Patterson Lakes]].<ref>[http://www.kingston.vic.gov.au/Page/Page.asp?Page_Id=1510 Kingston Library Service] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090518210024/http://www.kingston.vic.gov.au/Page/Page.asp?Page_Id=1510 |date=2009-05-18 }}</ref> * The [[City of Monash]] has libraries in [[Clayton, Victoria|Clayton]], [[Glen Waverley, Victoria|Glen Waverley]], [[Mount Waverley, Victoria|Mount Waverley]], [[Oakleigh, Victoria|Oakleigh]] and [[Wheelers Hill, Victoria|Wheelers Hill]] <ref>[http://www.monlib.vic.gov.au/ Monash Public Library Service]</ref> * The [[Shire of Mornington Peninsula]] has libraries in [[Mornington, Victoria, Australia|Mornington]], [[Rosebud, Victoria|Rosebud]], [[Hastings, Victoria|Hastings]] and [[Somerville, Victoria|Somerville]].<ref>[http://ourlibrary.mornpen.vic.gov.au/ Mornington Peninsula Library]</ref> * The [[City of Stonnington]] has libraries in [[Malvern, Victoria|Malvern]], [[Malvern East, Victoria|Malvern East]], [[Prahran, Victoria|Prahran]] and [[South Yarra, Victoria|South Yarra]].<ref>[http://www.stonnington.vic.gov.au/www/html/495-library-home.asp Stonnington Library and Information Service] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090518195831/http://www.stonnington.vic.gov.au/www/html/495-library-home.asp |date=2009-05-18 }}</ref>
'''Western suburbs''' * The [[City of Brimbank]] has libraries in [[Deer Park, Victoria|Deer Park]], [[Keilor, Victoria|Keilor]], [[St Albans, Victoria|St Albans]], [[Sunshine, Victoria|Sunshine]] and [[Sydenham, Victoria|Sydenham]].<ref>[http://www.brimbanklibraries.vic.gov.au/ Brimbank Library]</ref> * The [[City of Hobsons Bay]] has libraries in [[Altona, Victoria|Altona]], [[Altona Meadows, Victoria|Altona Meadows]], [[Altona North, Victoria|Altona North]], [[Newport, Victoria|Newport]] and [[Williamstown, Victoria|Williamstown]].<ref>[http://libraries.hobsonsbay.vic.gov.au/ Hobsons Bay Libraries]</ref> * The [[City of Maribyrnong]] has libraries in [[Braybrook, Victoria|Braybrook]], [[Footscray, Victoria|Footscray]], [[Maribyrnong, Victoria|Maribyrnong]], [[West Footscray, Victoria|West Footscray]] and [[Yarraville, Victoria|Yarraville]].<ref>[http://www.maribyrnong.vic.gov.au/Page/Page.asp?Page_Id=51&h=-1&p=1 Maribyrnong Libraries]</ref> * The [[Shire of Melton]] has libraries in [[Melton, Victoria (suburb)|Melton]] and [[Caroline Springs, Victoria|Caroline Springs]].<ref>[http://www.melton.vic.gov.au/Page/Page.asp?Page_Id=125&h=1&p=1 Melton Library and Information Service] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090523054602/http://www.melton.vic.gov.au/Page/Page.asp?Page_Id=125&h=1&p=1 |date=2009-05-23 }}</ref> * The [[City of Wyndham]] has libraries in [[Hoppers Crossing, Victoria|Hoppers Crossing]], [[Werribee, Victoria|Werribee]], [[Point Cook, Victoria|Point Cook]], [[Wyndham Vale, Victoria|Wyndham Vale]] and [[Tarneit, Victoria|Tarneit]].<ref>[http://www.wyndham.vic.gov.au/leisure/library Wyndham Library Service] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090523062017/http://www.wyndham.vic.gov.au/leisure/library |date=2009-05-23 }}</ref>
== State Government libraries == The State Government of Victoria maintains libraries within most Government departments and agencies as well as the through the [[State Library of Victoria]], the principal reference and research library of the State Government.
== Theological libraries == * Mannix Library,<ref>{{Cite web|title = MANNIX|url = https://cccv.ent.sirsi.net/client/en_GB/mannix|website = cccv.ent.sirsi.net|access-date = 2016-02-09}}</ref> Catholic Theological College * St Paschal Library,<ref>{{Cite web|title = Home - St Paschal Library|url = http://www.vspc-franciscan.org.au/|website = www.vspc-franciscan.org.au|access-date = 2016-02-09}}</ref> [[Box Hill, Victoria|Box Hill]]
== University Residential College libraries == * [[Ormond College]] Library,<ref>{{Cite web|title = Ormond College Library|url = http://ormc.sdp.sirsidynix.net.au/client/en_AU/default/|website = ormc.sdp.sirsidynix.net.au|access-date = 2016-02-09}}</ref> [[University of Melbourne|The University of Melbourne]] * [[Trinity College (University of Melbourne)|Trinity College]] Library,<ref>{{Cite web|title = Library {{!}} Trinity College - The University of Melbourne|url = http://www.trinity.unimelb.edu.au/learning/resources/library.html|website = www.trinity.unimelb.edu.au|access-date = 2016-02-09}}</ref> [[University of Melbourne|The University of Melbourne]]
== University libraries == *The University Library, [[University of Melbourne#Libraries|The University of Melbourne]]<ref>[http://www.lib.unimelb.edu.au/collections Discipline-specific collections in the University Library at the University of Melbourne]</ref> *Borchardt Library,.<ref>[[Dietrich Borchardt]], en.wikipedia.org. Retrieved on 12 October 2016.</ref> [[La Trobe University]] *[[RMIT University Library]] *[[Monash University]] Library *[[Swinburne University of Technology]] Library *[[Victoria University, Australia|Victoria University]] Library *[[Deakin University]] Library
== Library sponsors, donors and foundations == [[State Library of Victoria]] Foundation
==See also== * [[Casey Cardinia Libraries]] * [[Eastern Regional Libraries]] * [[Whitehorse Manningham Libraries]] * [[Wyndham City Libraries]] * [[Yarra Plenty Regional Library, Victoria, Australia]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.dpcd.vic.gov.au/localgovernment/find-a-public-library Find your local library]
{{Library nav}}

page.title: List of privately owned public spaces in New York City

revision.comment: add link
revision.text:
[[Privately owned public space]]s (POPS) in [[New York City]] were introduced in a 1961 zoning resolution. The city offers zoning concessions to commercial and residential developers in exchange for a variety of spaces accessible and usable for the public. There are approximately 503 POPS<ref name="APOPS">{{cite web|title=Privately Owned Public Space|url=http://apops.mas.org/|work=apops.mas.org/|publisher=Municipal Art Society|accessdate=5 November 2012}}</ref> at 320 buildings in New York City and are found principally in [[Manhattan]]. Spaces range from extended sidewalks to indoor [[Atrium (architecture)|atriums]] with seating and amenities. International attention was brought to POPS during the [[Occupy Wall Street]] movement begun in 2011 in [[Zuccotti Park]].<ref name="Meet Me at the Plaza">{{cite news|last=Kayden|first=Jerold S.|title=Meet Me at the Plaza|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/20/opinion/zuccotti-park-and-the-private-plaza-problem.html?_r=2&|accessdate=5 November 2012|newspaper=New York Times|date=19 October 2012}}</ref>
==List== List of noteworthy spaces.<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Privately-Owned-Public-Space-Experience/dp/0471362573/%20Privately%20Owned%20Public%20Space:%20The%20New%20York%20City%20Experience%5D Privately Owned Public Spaces: The New York City Experience by Jerold S. Kayden]</ref><ref>[http://www.nyc.gov/html/dcp/html/priv/priv.shtml Privately Owned Public Spaces] New York City Department of City Planning complete list and maps</ref>
===Manhattan===
====Downtown==== * [[17 State Street]] * 125 Broad Street, 2 New York Plaza * 85 Broad Street, [[Oppenheimer Holdings]] * [[55 Water Street]] * 77 Water Street * 32 Old Slip, Financial Square * 111 Wall Street * 75 Wall Street, [[Barclays]] Bank * 88 Pine Street, Wall Street Plaza * 180 Maiden Lane * 200 Water Street * 59 Maiden Lane * 10 Liberty Street * [[60 Wall Street]], Deutsche Bank * 40 Broad Street * 17 Battery Place, [[Whitehall Building]] * 33 Maiden Lane, Two Federal Preserve Plaza * 55 Church Street, [[Millenium Hilton Hotel]] * 105 Duane Street, Tribeca Tower * [[388 Greenwich Street]], Salomon Smith Barney * [[LentSpace]] * [[Zuccotti Park]], [[One Liberty Plaza]]
====West Side==== * 300 Mercer Street * 99 Jane Street * 650 West 42nd Street, River Place * 825 Eighth Avenue, [[One Worldwide Plaza]] * [[6½ Avenue]] * 322 West 57th Street, BMW * 1000 Tenth Avenue, St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital Center * 200 West 60th Street, Concerto * 45 West 60th Street, Regent * 30 West 61st Street, Beaumont * One Central Park West, [[Trump International Hotel and Tower (New York City)|Trump International Hotel and Tower]] * 1886 Broadway, 30 Lincoln Plaza * [[One Lincoln Plaza]] * 75 West End Avenue * 2 Lincoln Square * 145 West 67th Street, Tower 67 * 1991 Broadway, Bel Canto

revision.text:
{{Notability|Biographies|date=July 2009}} [[Image:Jorge Manuel do Carmo.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Manuel Carmo]]
'''Jorge Manuel do Carmo Pereira de Almeida''' (b. [[Lisbon]], 1958 - 2015) was a [[Portugal|Portuguese]] [[artist]] and [[author]].
Having practised as a [[lawyer]], he performed, in earlier years, as a deputy to the [[Chairmanship]] of the [[Council of Ministers of Portugal|Council of Ministers]] during the VII [[Constitutional]] [[Government]], as [[Chairman]] of the European cooperation NGO Latin American Studies Institute, and as Chairman of the Board in various [[multinational companies]]. In the early 1980s, he studied [[painting]] at Ar.Co, [[Lisbon]] and since then devoted himself exclusively to [[painting]], [[sculpture]] and [[writing]]. His first exhibition dates from 1985 and he has since been present in many exhibitions and conferences in [[Portugal]] and abroad. In 2000 he was awarded the Mention of Honour by the I Painting Biannual Domingos Sequeira and, in 2007, the First Prize of the Portuguese Association for Institutional Communication.
==The author==
Manuel Carmo is, at present, consultant of the European Museum Forum (Portugal) and also consultant for Aporem (an association integrating 17 museums) international projects.
Since January 2007, he has accepted responsibilities in the Museum of Water of [[Coimbra]], as [[Executive director]] of the [[Cultural]] and Contents Department and is the Chairman of AABA Arts Editions.
He was the [[Bairro Alto]] Art Gallery’ Arts Director and as such organized important exhibitions of reputed painters, such as [[Andy Warhol]], [[Tom Wesselmann]], [[Erró]], [[Gerard Schlosser]] and [[Joyce Tenneson]].
His life and work were the subject for a 30 min documentary, in 2005, produced by the Portuguese Public Television Channel [[RTP1]] in collaboration with Universidade Aberta, and broadcast through [[Rádio e Televisão de Portugal|RTP]] International channel.
Carmo was the single [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] [[Painting|painter]] invited to submit a project - Let’s Art! - to the [[UNESCO]] World Conferente on Education through the Arts, in 2006. Sanchez Bravo, the Chairman of the [[UNESCO]] Spanish Committee considers his painting as "a new nude and harmonious-musical path to transcend truth".
His most recent exhibition/performance in [[Portugal]], in 2005, entitled "1755 – the Cemetery of Hope or the 7 Virtues for Rebirth", evoking the 250th anniversary of the [[Lisbon]] 1755 earthquake, was honoured by the high patronage of H.E. the [[President of Portugal|President of the Republic]], Mr. [[Jorge Sampaio]].
In 2006, at the "[[Angel Orensanz Center|Angel Orensanz Foundation Center for the Arts]]", in [[New York City]], he exhibited a set of works on the creative act in Art, named "Manifesto 24", which included [[painting]], [[sculpture]] and [[video]]. On this exhibition, the New-Yorker art reviewer Nancy di Benedetto said, “the best homage one may pay to '''Manuel Carmo''' is the acknowledgement that his works do not belong to any predetermined schools nor [[Art movement|movements]] as they challenge categorization and opens the path for new territories for the [[Arts]] in the twenty first century”.
Carmo is regularly invited to lecture on [[Art]], within the scope of activities of [[UNESCO]], "Collect and Share" and "Life Long Learning" projects, and also the [[European Union|EU]] "[[Socrates]]" and "[[N. F. S. Grundtvig|Grundtvig]]" programmes.
==Represented==
Quoted in the [[New York City]] Arts Annual Catalogue 2007, he is represented in various foundations and museums. Amongst these: *Antonio Prates Foundation *Michettti Foundation *European Museum Forum *International Museum of Graphic Art *Mumi Museum *[[Madeira]] Museum of Contemporary Arts *EPAL Museum of Water *[[Chaves Municipality, Portugal|Chaves]] City Hall *[[Bragança Municipality|Bragança]] City Hall * [[Lisbon]] City Hall *Mundial Confiança *Universitária Editora *[[Bairro Alto]] Art Ateliers *Portuguese [[Serigraphy]] Centre *Mission Structure Against Home Abuse *[[Angel Orensanz Center]] *[[Mário Soares]] Foundation *Beni Culturali Emília Romagna Institute, Italy *Portuguese Communications Foundation *Museum of Communications *Avilez Cultural Centre *Museum of Water of [[Coimbra]] *[[Queen Fabiola of Belgium]]’s Collection *[[Chico Buarque]] de Holanda’s Collection *[[Fausto Bertinotti]]’s Collection *International Medical Assistance's Collection
==Published works on art==
*"Aquae Liberae Triumphalis Ingressus", Editorial Hugin, 2004. *"Um Café pelo Aqueduto", Editorial ACD, 2005. *"A Diferença para +", Ateliers de Arte do Bairro Alto, 2005. *"1755 – Cemitério de Esperança", Editorial ACD, 2005. *"Manifesto 24", Angel Orensanz Foundation (New York), 2005. *"Liberdade Número 800240574", Fundação Mário Soares, 2006. *"Acquit há Gato!", Museu das Comunicações, 2006. * "Os 7 Estados da Água", Edições AABA 2007
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090423125721/http://artscapemagazine.com/events.html Artscape Magazine Review] * [https://archive.is/20121218142630/http://www.dillmuli.feek.pte.hu/lconf.htm Lisbon Conference Website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070521015936/http://www.manuel-carmo.com/ Manuel Carmo Artist Website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081119135152/http://www.manuelcarmofoundation.com/homeEn.html Manuel Carmo Foundation Website]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Carmo, Manuel}} [[Category:Portuguese painters]] [[Category:Contemporary painters]] [[Category:Portuguese male writers]] [[Category:Lecturers]] [[Category:Art educators]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1958 births]] [[Category:People from Lisbon]]

revision.comment: /* Recent winners */
revision.text:
The '''Michigan Mathematics Prize Competition (MMPC)''' is an annual high school mathematics competition held in Michigan. First founded in 1958, the competition has grown to include over 10,000 high school participants (although middle-schoolers may also participate through a high school). The director and host of this competition changes every three years, the most recent director being Stephanie Edwards of Hope College. This competition consists of two parts, which are added together to determine score:
: Part I: A 40 question, multiple-choice exam open to all Michigan high schoolers
: Part II: A 5 question, proof exam given only to the Top 1000 scorers on Part I
The Top 100 scorers on the combined score of both parts of the competition are honored at an awards banquet, usually at the host university, although recent years have seen more than 100 people being awarded due to ties.
==Problem difficulty==
The problems on the competition range from basic [[algebra]] to [[precalculus]] and are within the grasp of a high schooler's mathematical knowledge. The contest contains concepts from a variety of topics, including [[geometry]] and [[combinatorics]].
== Grading ==
Part I has 40 multiple-choice questions. One point is awarded for each correct answer, giving a maximum score of forty points.
Part II has five ten point proof-based problems. The test is graded out of fifty points. This part is weighted x1.2, so the total amount of points possible is 60.
The highest possible score on this test is 100 points (summing the Part I and Part II scores).
It is common for the winner of the competition to score anywhere from 90 to 95 points due to the difficulty of the exam. It sometimes falls even lower due to especially tough exams.
The only perfect scores were achieved in 2015, by Ankan Bhattacharya of International Academy East, and in 2016, by Chittesh Thavamani and Freddie Zhao, both of Troy High School. 2016 also marked the year of the highest scoring 3rd, 4th, and 5th place winners in MMPC history with 3rd place scoring 99 points, 4th place scoring 98.8 points, and 5th place scoring 97.6 points.
==Awards==
The Top 100 are invited to an awards banquet. Although the Top 50 are denoted as "bronze," no actual medal is awarded. Likewise, the Top 10 and Top 3 are called "silver" and "gold" (respectively) but do not receive medals.
The Lower 50 are deemed "honorable mentions" and receive a gift card/certificate/book.
Everyone in the Top 50 receives a scholarship ranging in size from $250 to $2500
In the 2012 contest, Akhil Nistala became the first winner in Novi High School history, breaking a streak of 6 consecutive top scorers for Detroit Country Day School.
==Recent winners== 2017: Grace Zheng, [[Skyline High School (Michigan) | Ann Arbor Skyline High School]]
2016: Chittesh Thavamani, [[Troy High School (Michigan)|Troy High School]] Freddie Zhao, [[Troy High School (Michigan)|Troy High School]]
2015: Ankan Bhattacharya, [[International Academy#East Campus|International Academy East]]
2014: Jacqueline Bredenberg, [[Detroit Country Day School]]
2013: Jacqueline Bredenberg, [[Detroit Country Day School]]
2012: Akhil Nistala, [[Novi High School]]
2011: David Lu, [[Detroit Country Day School]]
2010: Allen Yuan, [[Detroit Country Day School]]
2009: Allen Yuan, [[Detroit Country Day School]]
2008: Allen Yuan, [[Detroit Country Day School]]
2007: Alan Huang, [[Detroit Country Day School]]
2006: Alan Huang, [[Detroit Country Day School]]
2005: Frederic Sala, [[Troy High School (Michigan)|Troy High School]]
2004: John Zhou, [[Detroit Country Day School]]
2003: Anant Gupta, [[Troy High School (Michigan)|Troy High School]]
2002: Robert Hough, [[Dow High School]]
2001: Mike Asmar, [[Troy High School (Michigan)|Troy High School]]
2000: Qian Zhang, [[Winston Churchill High School (Livonia, Michigan)#Math, Science, and Computer program|Livonia MSC Program]]
1999: Qian Zhang, [[Winston Churchill High School (Livonia, Michigan)#Math, Science, and Computer program|Livonia MSC Program]]
1998: Michael Khoury Jr., [[Brother Rice High School (Michigan)|Brother Rice High School]]
1997: J. Benjamen Hough, [[Dow High School|H.H. Dow High School]]
1996: Bryant Matthews, [[Forest Hills Northern High School]]
1995: Amit Khetan, [[ICAE]]
1994: Amit Khetan, [[ICAE]]
1993: Amit Khetan, [[ICAE]]
==External links== {{nofootnotes|date=June 2014}} * [http://www.emich.edu/math/mmpc/ MMPC Website for 2015-present] * [http://math.hope.edu/mmpc/ MMPC Website for 2011–2014] * [https://archive.is/20130415090758/http://www.michmaa.org/newsletter.html Previous MMPC Newsletters with Names of MMPC Winners] * [http://www.svsu.edu/mmpc/ MMPC Website for 2008-2010] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110720015228/http://www.math.oakland.edu/tempmmpc/index.html MMPC Website for 2006–2007] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100530121729/http://www.albion.edu/mathcs/mmpc/ MMPC Website for 2002–2004] * [https://archive.is/20130415080157/http://www.michmaa.org/history/mmpc.html Michigan Mathematical Association of America MMPC Article]
